etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Saturday Review. From live + -ness

definitions: The quality or condition of being alive.
The property of a room or enclosure, or of a recording, of having a long reverberation time.
The quality or condition (of an event, performance, etc.) of being heard, watched, or broadcast at the time of occurrence.
The property of a circuit, program, or process of giving a good or useful outcome.

notes.text: Contrasted with safety, the property of not giving a bad or useless outcome.
